awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Synthesizing arc-scale geochemical, petrologic, and geophysical datasets to investigate causes of volcanic diversity in the Cascade Arc
awd_abstract_narration:
Subduction zones – locations where one of the Earth’s tectonic plates are pushed beneath another – are one of the most volcanically active environments on the planet. Decades of study on subduction zones have provided insight into the overarching processes that produce the magmas erupted, how the erupted magmas are produced at individual volcanoes, and a number of related questions. Despite this progress, a complex and largely unsolved problem is the cause of ubiquitous and dramatic variations in the amount and composition of magmas that erupt at volcanoes within the same subduction zone. Do these reflect processes acting deep within the Earth’s mantle, or in the overlying crust? Addressing this problem has important implications for understanding magma production and volcanic hazards, as worldwide almost a billion people live at risk from volcanoes. There is also a potential for scientific breakthrough by utilizing the existing large data sets acquired from recent NSF investments such as the MARGINS, GeoPRISMS, and EarthScope programs. However, addressing the question has proven challenging to date in part because of a lack of critical data for some locations, but largely because of the lack of suitable tools and approaches that allow us to quantitatively synthesize and compare the existing large data sets. 

Thus, this is a multidisciplinary study to conduct a quantitative comparison of existing large geophysical and compositional datasets at the spatial scales of the entire Cascades subduction zone, linked through sets of common intensive variables such as heat and density, to determine the primary drivers of intra-arc magmatic diversity. Building on a successful Proof of Concept project that demonstrates the promise of the approach (Till et al., 2019), the project will test hypotheses about the relative roles of mantle magmatic flux vs. crustal characteristics and crustal magma storage depths in producing variations in erupted compositions and fluxes, and in controlling the geophysical state of the crust along strike in the Quaternary Cascades arc. The project has the potential to transform our understanding of these important regions and will produce a number of important broader impacts including, catalyzing interdisciplinary collaborations between three PI’s at three institutions, producing expert datasets widely and easily available to the Earth Science community, supporting undergraduate experiential learning activities. Specifically, it will implement a new multi-year undergraduate research program CONVEcT program (Central Oregon Network for Volcano Education and Training) with research cohorts from Arizona State, Oregon State and Cornell Universities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Subduction zones – locations where one of the Earth’s tectonic plates are pushed beneath another – are one of the most volcanically active environments on the planet. Despite decades of scientific progress studying these locations, a largely unsolved problem is the cause of dramatic variations in the amount and composition of magmas that erupt at volcanoes within the same subduction zone. Are these variations caused by processes in the Earth’s mantle, or in the overlying crust? Addressing this problem has important implications for understanding magma production and volcanic hazards, as worldwide almost a billion people live at risk from volcanoes.

 

To work on this problem, this grant tested to two hypotheses: (1) that the observed diversity in arc volcanic phenomena (e.g., composition, erupted volume, and edifice type) in the Cascades volcanic arc results from variations in the amount of magma generated in the mantle beneath each volcano, or alternatively, (2) that the observed diversity results from differences in where and what type of crust the magma are stored in prior to eruption. 

 

To test Hypothesis #1, the grant supported Dr. Andrea Goltz (a postdoctoral fellow at Arizona State University mentored by PI Till and Co-I Kent) to construct a box model used with a Monte Carlo modeling approach to determine the primary variables controlling the volume of magma that can be generated in the Earth’s mantle beneath Cascades arc volcanoes. As part of constructing the model, Dr. Goltz also compiled previously determined experimental melting rates (i.e., volume of melt generated per increment of time in laboratory experiments). The results of the modeling do not refute Hypothesis #1, thereby leaving open the possibility that variations in the amount of magma generated in the mantle beneath the volcanoes may cause the observed variations in their eruptive behavior.

 

To test Hypothesis #2, the grant supported Dr. Penny Wieser (a postdoctoral fellow at Oregon State University mentored by Co-I Kent & PI Till) to apply mineral and mineral-melt barometers to determine the pressure of crustal magma storage beneath the Cascades arc volcanoes. As part of this effort, Dr. Wieser developed an open-source tool in Python3 to apply almost all previously published magma thermobarometry tools (each of which had their own method of application by hand, in excel etc.). Additionally, Dr. Wieser used this tool to demonstrate cause and size of previously underappreciated errors in magma barometric calculations, as well as discuss how to minimize these errors in the future in two additional publications. Finally, Dr. Wieser applied the new thermobarometric tool to find that magma storage depths are remarkably consistent beneath all Cascades volcanoes (2 kbar ± 2 kbar). This invalidates Hypothesis #2 and suggests that the location of magma storage is NOT a main control on producing the observed diversity of volcanic phenomenon. This publication also discusses the extremely limited amount of data available for these types of calculations at some of the U.S.’s highest threat volcanoes (e.g., Glacier Peak, Mt. Baker, Mt. Hood, and Three Sisters), emphasizing the need to continue to study these systems.

 

In a third effort, Dr. Guanning Pang (a postdoctoral fellow at Cornell University mentored by Co-I Abers, who is funded in part through other means), utilized seismic waves recorded at newly installed near-summit seismometers at many Cascades volcanoes to locate the tops of magma bodies. This work also finds remarkably consistent magma storage depths, similar to the work by Dr. Wieser, and was presented at a highigh-profileoscience conference, in addition to being in review at a high profile scientific journal.

 

In conclusion, this multidisciplinary study used existing datasets to produce important discoveries about what causes the different eruptive behavior of volcanoes within the Cascades volcanic arc in the western US. Overall, we find that these eruptive differences are much more likely to be caused by variations in the amount of magma generated beneath the volcanoes, rather than differences in the storage history of those magmas while en route to the surface. These discoveries are documented in at least 6 newly published scientific papers with several more in review. In addition to the training provided to Dr.s Wieser and Goltz (both of whom now have full-time jobs in their fields), the grant supported several undergraduate research projects and field trips for students to volcanoes in the study area.
